description: From Middle English stond, stounde, stound (“hour, time, season, moment”), from Old English stund (“a period of time, while, hour, occasion”), from Proto-West Germanic *stundu, from Proto-Germanic *stundō (“point in time, hour”), from Proto-Indo-European *stut- (“prop”), from Proto-Indo-European *steh₂- (“to stand”).

Cognate with Dutch stond (“hour, time, moment”), German Stunde (“hour”), Danish stund (“time, while”), and Swedish stund (“time, while”). Compare Middle English stunden (“to linger, stay, remain for a while”), Icelandic stunda (“to frequent, pursue”). Related to stand.

examples: What booth wilt thou have? our king reply'd / Now tell me in this stound

entries.meaning: (archaic or dialectal) A time, length of time, hour, while.
examples: He lay and slept, and swet a stound, / And became whole and sound.

entries.meaning: (archaic or dialectal) A brief span of time, moment, instant.
examples: Listen to me a little stound.

entries.meaning: A moment or instance of urgency; exigence.
(dialectal) A sharp or sudden pain; a shock, an attack.
examples: No wonder that they cried unto the Lord, and felt a stound of despair shake their courage

entries.meaning: A stroke or blow (from an object or weapon); (by extension) a lashing; scourging
examples: How many pipes, as many sounds Do still impart To your Sonne's hart / As many deadly wounds : How many strokes, as many stounds, Each stroke a dart, Each stound a smart, Poore captive me confounds.

entries.meaning: A fit, an episode or sudden outburst of emotion; a rush.
examples: Several stounds of pain in the cleft between great and second toe (anterior tibial nerve). I forget which side, but I think it was the right. Slight pains in left temple, > pressure. Pain in upper part of right eyeball.
we stood as in a stound, / And wet with tears, like dew, the ground

verbs.description: stound (third-person singular simple present stounds, present participle stounding, simple past and past participle stounded)

entries.meaning: (obsolete or dialectal, intransitive) To hurt, pain, smart.
examples: Your wrath, weak boy ? Tremble at mine unless
Retraction follow close upon the heels

entries.meaning: (obsolete or dialectal, intransitive) To be in pain or sorrow, mourn.
(obsolete or dialectal, intransitive) To long or pine after, desire.
examples: Recently weaned children "stound after the breast."

description: From Middle English stunden (“to linger, stay, remain for a while”). Cognate with Icelandic stunda (“to frequent, pursue”). More at stand.

verbs.description: stound (third-person singular simple present stounds, present participle stounding, simple past and past participle stounded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, UK dialectal) To stop to listen; pause.

description: From Middle English stound, stonde, stoonde, ston, from Old English stond (“a stand”). Compare stand.

entries.meaning: A receptacle for holding small beer.
examples: Will Ardnamurchan never end? We're four stounds in a metal box [...]
